titleStmt.title: IgG and IgG 4 to 91 allergenic molecules in early childhood by route of exposure and current and future IgE sensitization: Results from the Multicentre Allergy Study birth cohort

affiliation.orgName: Department of Pediatric Pneumology and Immunology

analytic.title: IgG and IgG 4 to 91 allergenic molecules in early childhood by route of exposure and current and future IgE sensitization: Results from the Multicentre Allergy Study birth cohort

biblStruct.note: Received for publication June 30, 2015; revised December 14, 2015; accepted for publication January 22, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Background: Studies of a limited number of allergens suggested that nonsensitized children produce IgG responses mainly to foodborne allergens, whereas IgE-sensitized children also produce strong IgG responses to the respective airborne molecules.
Objective: We sought to systematically test the hypothesis that both the route of exposure and IgE sensitization affect IgG responses to a broad array of allergenic molecules in early childhood.
Methods: We examined sera of 148 children participating in the Multicentre Allergy Study, a birth cohort born in 1990.
IgG to 91 molecules of 42 sources were tested with the ImmunoCAP Solid-Phase Allergen Chip (ISAC; TFS, Uppsala, Sweden).
IgE sensitization at age 2 and 7 years was defined by IgE levels of 0.35 kU A /L or greater to 1 or more of 8 or 9 extracts from common allergenic sources, respectively.

Results: The prevalence and geometric mean levels of IgG to allergenic molecules in nonsensitized children were lower at age 2 years than in IgE-sensitized children, and they were extremely heterogeneous: highest for animal food (87% 6 13%; 61 ISAC Standardized Units [ISU], [95% CI, 52.5-71.5 ISU]), intermediate for vegetable food (48% 6 27%; 13 ISU [95% CI, 11.2-16.1 ISU]), and lowest for airborne allergens (24% 6 20%; 3 ISU [95% CI, 2.4-3.4
ISU]; P for trend < .001
[for percentages], P for trend < .001
[for levels]).
IgG 4 antibodies were infrequent (<5%) and contributed poorly (<3%) to overall IgG antibody levels.
IgG responses at age 2 years were slightly more frequent and stronger among children with than in those without IgE sensitization at age 7 years.

Conclusion: The children's repertoire of IgG antibodies at 2 years of age to a broad array of animal foodborne, vegetable foodborne, and airborne allergenic molecules is profoundly dependent on the route of allergen exposure and the child's IgE sensitization status and only marginally involves the IgG 4 isotype.
The role played by IgG antibodies in allergic reactions, unlike that of IgE, 1,2 is still debated.
IgG antibodies are considered to be nonpathogenic 3 or even protective, 4 and because they occur within the course of and after immunotherapy, 5 they are labeled as blocking antibodies. 6
However, allergen-specific IgG might also play a role in anaphylactic events 7 and could develop in parallel with or even preceding IgE antibodies. 8
IgG has been seen generally as a marker of natural exposure. 9

The IgG response against allergens starts in general as an IgG 1 -dominated response and, on continued exposure, can gradually shift toward an IgG 4 -dominated response, 10 a phenomenon also characterizing allergen-specific immunotherapy. 11
he IgG responses to animal foods are frequent in childhood, 12 whereas little epidemiologic information is available about IgG responses to inhalant allergens in early childhood.
][15][16][17][18][19] Also, it has been suggested that IgG responses in early childhood to certain allergenic molecules might even predict IgE sensitization later in life. 20,21

Altogether, information on the effect of the route of exposure and allergic predisposition on allergen-specific IgG responses is sparse, and no study in early childhood has simultaneously investigated the IgG repertoire to a wide range of molecules.
Before 2000, most studies of allergen-specific IgG responses were performed with assays based on allergenic extracts.
These tests were hampered by a high nonspecific background signal caused by extract contaminants recognized by the normal human IgG repertoire.

The availability of purified native or recombinant allergenic molecules printed on microarrays has recently allowed systematic study of the serum antibody repertoire with a few microliters of serum only. 8,15

Using this microarray approach, we have recently compared IgG and IgE responses to a panel of 7 foodborne and 3 airborne pathogenesis-related protein 10 (PR-10) molecules in birch-sensitized and nonsensitized children of the Multicentre Allergy Study (MAS) cohort. 8

This study allowed discrimination of a default weak IgG response driven by foodborne PR-10 molecules and detectable in both healthy and birch-sensitized children from a (pre-)atopic strong IgG response driven by airborne PR-10 molecules and detectable in birch-sensitized children only. 8

herefore the present study aimed to test the working hypothesis that IgG responses to environmental noninfectious antigens in infancy are influenced by 2 major determinants: the route of exposure in early childhood to that antigen and the individual predisposition of IgE sensitization.

To this end, we examined the IgG responses at 2 years of age against 91 allergenic molecules in a subset of 148 children of the MAS cohort, and we related these responses to the presence of IgE sensitization at 2 and 7 years of age.
The MAS, a prospective observational birth cohort study, recruited 1314 of 7609 infants born in 1990 on 6 delivery wards in 5 German cities (Berlin, D€ usseldorf, Mainz, Freiburg, and Munich).
A detailed description of the stratified sampling scheme and study subjects is presented elsewhere. 22,23
The study was approved by the local ethics committee.
Each parent provided written informed consent at the time of enrollment.
For the present study, only children whose serum data on IgE sensitization were available at both 2 and 7 years of age and whose serum was still available at 2 years of age were included.

IgE sensitization at 2 or 7 years of age was defined as the presence of specific IgE antibodies in serum (cutoff, > _0.35 kU A /L; ImmunoCAP, Thermo Fisher Scientific [TFS], Uppsala, Sweden) to at least 1 of the common allergenic extracts tested in the MAS birth cohort study at age 2 years (milk, egg, soy, wheat, house dust mite, cat, birch, and grass) or 7 years (milk, egg, soy, wheat, house dust mite, cat, dog, birch, and grass), respectively. 24

div.head: Assessment of IgG and IgG 4 antibodies against allergenic molecules

p.s: IgG antibodies to native and recombinant allergenic molecules were tested in sera diluted 1:50 with a multiplex microarray approach (ImmunoCAP Solid-Phase Allergen Chip [ISAC] 103 and 112; TFS), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
The 91 molecules that were available and comparable in both multiplex assays were taken into account for the present analysis.

Results were expressed in ISAC Standardized Units (ISU), with a cutoff point for positivity of 0.1 ISU. 15 IgG 4 antibodies against the same molecules have been tested with ImmunoCAP ISAC 112 (TFS), and the results have been expressed in ISU (cutoff for positivity, > _0.1 ISU). 15

div.head: Assessment of IgG antibodies against allergenic sources

p.s: Results obtained at the molecular level were also used to analyze outcomes at the source level.
Molecules belonging to sources with irrelevant exposure in the first 2 years of life in Germany (eg, Brazil nut, pellitory, and olive pollen) were excluded from analyses at the source level.
When 2 highly cross-reacting molecules belonging to the same source were tested (eg, Phl p 5 and Phl p 6), one of them was excluded (eg, Phl p 6).

Highly cross-reacting molecules belonging to different categories with different routes of exposure (eg, PR-10 molecules, profilin, and serum albumin) have also been excluded, with the only exception being Bet v 1, which has been used as a marker of sensitization to birch pollen.
Overall, analyses at the source level included 35 molecules and 16 sources (see Fig E1 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.
org).
The presence of serum IgG to a given molecule was defined by a level equal to or greater than 0.1 ISU, as previously described. 8,15
IgG responses to a given allergenic source were defined by the presence of IgG antibodies against at least 1 of its examined species-specific molecules.
The IgG concentration to each allergenic source was calculated by summing up the positive levels of IgG antibodies to each of the non-cross-reacting molecules belonging to that allergenic source.
Comparison of prevalence values.
Comparisons of the frequency of general characteristics between participants included and excluded from the present analysis were examined by using x 2 tests.

Comparisons of the general characteristics and prevalence of IgG responses to allergenic molecules and sources between IgE-sensitized and nonsensitized participants at 2 or 7 years of age were examined by using x 2 test or Fisher exact tests, when required.

div.head: Comparison of levels of IgG to allergenic sources.

p.s: Geometric mean levels of positive IgG responses to allergenic sources were calculated within the subpopulations of IgE-sensitized and nonsensitized subjects and expressed in ISU.
A t test was used to compare the logarithmic average values of IgG levels to allergenic sources of sensitized versus nonsensitized children at 2 and 7 years of age.
Comparison of prevalence of IgG responses to the 3 allergenic categories.

The mean prevalence (and its SD) of IgG responses to the allergenic molecules within the 3 categories of animal foodborne, vegetable foodborne, and airborne allergens were calculated in IgE-sensitized and nonsensitized children at 2 years of age.
These mean values were then compared, and a P value was estimated by using a mixed logistic model in which subjects accounted for the random effects.
A mixed logistic regression was also used to evaluate the trend of IgG prevalence across the 3 categories of exposure.

In this last analysis the 3 categories were hierarchically ordered according to the proportion and dose of ingested allergen: animal foodborne (ingested early in infancy and at high frequency and dose), vegetable foodborne (ingested later in infancy or at a lower frequency and dose), and airborne (inhaled at minimal doses).
Comparison of levels of IgG responses to the 3 allergenic categories.

The overall concentration of IgG antibodies to animal foodborne, vegetable foodborne, and airborne allergens were calculated in each participant by summing up the positive levels of IgG antibodies against each of the molecules belonging to the respective category.
The geometric mean (95% CI) of these values was obtained in the groups of IgE-sensitized and nonsensitized children at 2 years of age, respectively.
Then a t test on logarithmic values was used to compare the category level of IgE-sensitized versus nonsensitized children at 2 years of age.
Software and P values.
Statistical analyses were performed with Stata 13.1 software (StataCorp, College Station, Tex).
A P value of less than .05
was considered statistically significant.
Overall, 148 children (75 boys) of the 1314 recruited in the MAS birth cohort were included in the present study.

The included children did not differ significantly from those not included regarding sex, parental education, and parental history of allergy, whereas they were more frequently of German nationality, had older siblings, and had been breast-fed.
Among the 148 participants, 25 (17%) children were IgE sensitized at 2 years of age and 51 (34%) at 7 years of age (see Table E1 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).
At 2 years of age, most of the IgE-sensitized children (52%) were sensitized to milk (foodborne) compared with only a quarter (25%) at 7 years of age.

On the other hand, at 7 years of age, more than half of the children (65%) were sensitized to grass (airborne) compared with only 24% at 2 years of age (see Table E2 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).

The children with IgE sensitization at 2 years of age did not significantly differ from the nonsensitized children in regard to sex, nationality, parental education, older siblings, breast-feeding, and parental history of allergy.

Sixty-four percent of the IgE-sensitized children at age 2 years were still sensitized at age 7 years, whereas only 28% of the children who were nonsensitized at 2 years of age became sensitized at 7 years of age (Table I).
Interestingly, 97% of those seroconverted children became sensitized to at least 1 airborne source at 7 years of age, whereas just 37% became sensitized to a foodborne source.

Only 4 of the 9 children losing their IgE sensitization at age 7 years were sensitized to foodborne sources, whereas 5 were sensitized to airborne sources at age 2 years (see Table E3 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).

div.head: Prevalence of IgG responses in nonsensitized children

p.s: The frequency of the IgG responses to the 91 molecules was extremely heterogeneous in nonsensitized children at 2 years of age and ranged from 0% (Art v 1, mugwort) to 98% (Bos d 5, milk; Fig 1).
IgG responses to foodborne and airborne molecules tended to rank in the upper and lower halves of the prevalence spectrum, respectively.
Among IgG responses to food proteins, the 5 responses to cow milk proteins ranked in the first 5 positions, whereas IgG responses to Gal d 2 and Gal d 1 ranked 6th and 9th in the spectrum.
The majority of the IgG responses to vegetable food proteins appeared in the first half of the spectrum (Fig 1 ).

A few extreme exceptions to these trends can be observed: for example, IgG to Gal d 5 (egg) ranked 90th, and IgG to Phl p 1 and Phl p 4 (timothy grass) ranked 14th and 12th, respectively, whereas IgG to Der f 1 (Dermatophagoides farinae) and Bla g 1 (Blatella germanica) could be observed in the 11th and 8th positions (Fig 1).

div.head: Prevalence of IgG responses in IgE-sensitized children
Prevalence and levels of IgG 4 responses

p.s: We detected IgG 4 responses to only 38 of the 91 examined molecules.
The prevalence of the observed responses ranged from 1% to less than 20% in most cases (33/38) animal foodborne sources (milk and egg) were detected in more than 90%.
Responses to vegetable foodborne sources ranged between 47% (sesame) and 86% (hazelnut), and those to airborne sources ranged between 16% (birch) and 79% (timothy grass).
In each source the prevalence of IgG responses tended to be higher in IgE-sensitized than nonsensitized children, and this difference was significant for cashew nut (P < .05),
peanut (P < .01),
and D pteronyssinus (P <.01).
Levels of IgG to milk (P <.01), egg (P < .01),
kiwi (P < .05),
and peanut (P < .05)
were significantly higher in IgE-sensitized versus nonsensitized children (Fig 2 ).
Prevalence and concentration of IgG responses by allergen exposure

Among both nonsensitized and IgE-sensitized children, the overall prevalence of IgG responses was highest to animal food allergens, intermediate to vegetable food allergens, and lowest to airborne allergens (P for trend < .001).
These associations were also replicated when the geometric mean levels of IgG antibodies against the 3 categories of molecules were analyzed.

Lastly, IgE-sensitized children showed significantly higher prevalences of IgG and higher levels of the sum of detectable IgG (with the exception of the airborne group) than their nonsensitized peers in each of the 3 categories (Fig 3).
E4 in this article's Online Repository at www. jacionline.org).

Interestingly, 7-year-old children with an IgE sensitization to airborne allergenic sources showed a significantly higher prevalence of IgG responses to the same allergen category at 2 years of age than their nonsensitized peers, whereas this association was not found in the case of food allergens (see Fig E7 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).

In a subset of 148 children of the MAS birth cohort, we found that, with only a few exceptions, IgG responses in infancy to environmental noninfectious antigens are (1) associated with the route of exposure, (2) associated with the subject's capacity to produce IgE to common allergens, and (3) receive only infrequent and minimal contribution from the IgG 4 isotype.
To our knowledge, this is the first study describing the IgG repertoire to a broad range of allergenic molecules and their major determinants in a birth cohort.

div.head: Effect of exposure on IgG responses

p.s: The association between the route of allergen exposure and IgG responses clearly emerged in our study at the molecular and source level, such as by the quite impressive difference in the prevalence of IgG production between Cor a 1.0401 and Cor a 1.0101.
Cor a 1.0401 (33th position) is a foodborne PR-10 contained in hazelnut, whereas Cor a 1.0101 (73th position) is an airborne PR-10 contained in hazel pollen (Fig 1 ).
A few other studies examined this issue in previous decades.
In an American study IgG antibodies to milk and egg proteins were found in more than 95% of 2-year-old children at risk of allergic disease. 12

By contrast, only 41 (54%) of 76 American children who were highly exposed to Fel d 1 had an IgG response to Fel d 1. 4 Among 31 nonallergic American children, only 30% had an IgG response to Der p 1. 13 Finally, only 1 of 14 nonallergic Swedish children had detectable IgG 1 to Bet v 1. 25 These pieces of information from different populations, each focusing on a quite limited set of molecules or sources, 4,12,13,25 anticipated the comprehensive scenario shown by our study and suggested that IgG antibodies can be seen as a marker of allergen exposure. 9
he route of exposure could also help explain the opposite trend, when nonsensitized children show IgG production more often than IgE-sensitized children in some molecules.

Other than for milk, egg, and pollen, the exposure to molecules of some allergenic sources (eg, Anisakis simplex, insect venom, and codfish) can be extremely dependent on casual events (eg, ingestion of contaminated fish, insect sting, and family dietary habits).
Therefore this heterogeneity might explain the trends of IgG responses to Gad c 1, Ani s 1, Act d 5, and Api m 4.
However, Hev b 8 (profilin) represents an exception to this explanation.
Additionally, not just the route but also the amount of allergen exposure plays a role in IgE sensitization.
Indeed, a 2-year-old child who drinks 1 glass of milk (about 100 g) a day ingests annually about 80 g (ie, 80 millions of micrograms) of b-lactoglobulin. 26
The annual intake of vegetable food protein in European infants is in general less than that of animal food protein. 27

Lastly, a single grain of grass pollen contains on average only 2.3 pg (one millionth of a microgram) of Phl p 5, and in Germany approximately 2000 grass pollen grains are cumulatively dispersed per cubic meter per year. 28
his suggests that a German child inhales no more than a few micrograms of Phl p 5 per year.

Therefore our results also suggest that not only the route (ingestion vs inhalation) but also the overall amount of allergen exposure determines whether an IgG response to allergenic molecules will occur in early childhood.
A further determinant could be the antigenic potency of the molecule.
IgG responses to Phl p 1, the most potent allergen of Phleum pratense and the most frequent initiator of an IgE response to this pollen, 22 were observed in more than 70% of nonsensitized children.
Therefore one could assume that Phl p 1 is potent in inducing both IgG and IgE antibodies.

div.head: Effect of IgE sensitization on IgG responses

p.s: Our working hypothesis was that IgG production in early childhood is a marker for a higher propensity of producing antibodies in general (including IgE).
Hence we examined the association of IgG production with IgE sensitization to common allergens rather than to each individual molecule.

Our results show that the higher IgG prevalence in IgE-sensitized children is, at 2 years of age, spread all over the 91 molecules and is not strictly limited to the antigen inducing the IgE sensitization.
Our data clearly show that IgE-sensitized children produce more and stronger IgG responses to allergenic molecules.
Our systematic observations have been anticipated by studies limited to a few allergenic molecules. 13,14,18,20,29,30

Among Swedish children, allergic sensitization or symptoms correlated with high levels of IgG responses to ovalbumin, birch, and cat, 29 and IgG levels to b-lactoglobulin were greater in patients with mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis than in control subjects. 30
In Finnish children IgG responses to ovalbumin were associated with allergic disorders. 18
Moreover, serum IgG levels to rye grass pollen were related to total IgE levels in American children. 14

astly, the contribution of IgG 4 to the observed IgG responses was infrequent (<8% of the IgG-positive responses, <5% in all tests performed) and, when detected, quantitatively marginal (<3% in values positive for both IgG and IgG 4 ).

This result is consistent with data showing that IgG 4 responses are mostly induced by continuous administration of high levels of allergen (eg, in the case of allergen immunotherapy) 11 and are negligible in early childhood. 8
Accordingly, the highest prevalences of IgG 4 responses were found in animal food allergenic molecules.
We have to acknowledge some limitations of our study.
First, the included participants do not represent the whole MAS cohort or the German general population.
Therefore, although general conclusions are robust enough, associations concerning individual molecules might be context dependent and less reproducible in different settings.
Second, the ISAC test for IgG antibodies might not be sensitive enough to detect low IgG antibody levels.
However, this method was validated in previous studies in both our laboratory 8 and the laboratories of others. 15,31
hird, we did not test IgG 1 antibodies because the ISAC kit does not consider this possibility.
Nevertheless, to our knowledge, IgG 2 and IgG 3 responses to allergenic molecules are regarded as irrelevant.

Therefore considering the very low frequency and intensity of IgG 4 responses, we speculate that the vast majority of allergen-specific IgG responses observed in our study population are of the IgG 1 isotype.

Fourth, because we used IgE results already produced in 1992 in the MAS, 24 relevant allergens, such as peanut and tree nut, are missing in the panel of extracts for defining IgE sensitization in this study.
However, these molecules play a much smaller role in the life of a child than the ones used for the definition of IgE sensitization.
Fifth, because 2 different ImmunoCAP ISAC kits (103 and 112) were used for assessment of IgG antibodies, the results could be affected.

Nonetheless, we tested the reproducibility of validating comparability of results across 2 generations and concluded that the ''interkit'' variability among ISAC versions was similar to ''intrakit'' variability (data not shown, results available on request).
At the moment, a routine determination of IgG levels to potential allergens in the clinical setting cannot be recommended.
However, our study has biological implications.

A recent study 8 of antibody responses to 7 foodborne and 3 airborne PR-10 molecules introduced the concept of a ''default'' (ie, physiologic) IgG response directed mainly at ingested noninfectious antigens, as opposed to a ''preatopic'' IgG response directed mainly at airborne allergens in children with IgE sensitization as well.

The present study supports and further expands both concepts by systematically analyzing a very broad range of molecules from ingested and inhaled allergenic sources and by showing a greater frequency and concentration of IgG responses to allergens in children with IgE sensitization at 2 years of age.
The functional role of a default IgG response is unknown.
It might be linked to the development of tolerance, especially to food allergens, or it might be just an epiphenomenon with no functional relevance.
We also do not know whether IgG default responses play any role (preventing or facilitating) in the onset or evolution of an atopic response.
Weak and transient IgE responses can be also a normal epiphenomenon accompanying IgG default responses in children with a stronger propensity to produce antibodies in general.
Accordingly, we 32 and others 33 have shown that weak IgE responses (ie, <1 kU A /L) in infancy are often transient, and a high proportion of them disappear after a few years.

5][36][37] On the other hand, this and our previous study of the MAS cohort suggest that IgG to some airborne allergenic proteins (eg, PR-10) 8 marks true preatopic responses (ie, a response preceding and somehow predicting an IgE response to the same allergens).
Accordingly, it has been previously proposed that high levels of IgG to some allergens early in life might predict the development of IgE sensitization later in life. 20,21,38
Therefore this area of investigation is very complex, and further studies are now needed to define how default and preatopic IgG responses can be better discriminated.

div.head: Predictive factor of IgG at 2 years of age

p.s: A tendency can be seen when looking at the difference between weak and strong IgG producers.

Just 5% of the children belonging to the quartile of weak IgG producers at age 2 years were IgE sensitized at age 2 years, whereas in the quartile of strong IgG production, a higher percentage (22%) was IgE sensitized, while at age 7 years, no difference was observed (Table E4).
IgG prevalences to many foodborne molecules (27/41 [66%]) at 2 years of age were greater in children IgE sensitized at age 7 years than in their nonsensitized peers (Fig E6).
Additionally, for more than half of the molecules (28/41 [68%]), titers were also higher in children sensitized at age 7 years.
However, only in 4 (14%) of these 28 cases (Ara h 1, Ara h 2, Gly m 5, and Gly m 6) were these titers significantly higher.
This justifies the notion that global IgG responses to foodborne molecules at 2 years of age do not predict IgE sensitization at age 7 years.
Abbreviations used ISAC: ImmunoCAP Solid-Phase Allergen Chip ISU: ISAC Standardized Units MAS: Multicentre Allergy Study PR-10: Pathogenesis-related protein 10
higher percentage of IgG responses to allergenic molecules was detected among IgE-sensitized versus nonsensitized children (45% vs 36%, P <.001).

Statistical significance was reached in the case of 19 molecules, including Gal d 5 (egg), Act d 1 (kiwi), Ana o 2 (cashew), Ara h 1, Ara h 2, Ara h 3 (peanut), Cor a 1.0401 (hazelnut), Gly m 5, Gly m 6 (soy), Can f 3 (dog), Fel d 4 (cat), Der p 1, Der p 2 (Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus), Alt a 6 (Alternaria species), Art v 3 (mugwort), Cup a 1 (cypress), Phl p 4 (timothy grass) Phl p 5 (timothy grass), and Pla a 2 (plane tree).
By contrast, IgG responses to only 2 molecules (Hev b 8 [latex] and Act d 5 [kiwi]) were significantly less frequent in the sensitized group than in the nonsensitized group (Fig 1).
FIG 1. Prevalence of IgG responses to 91 allergenic molecules in 148 children of the MAS cohort at 2 years of age by IgE sensitization at 2 years of age.
Red and blue bars show the prevalence of detectable IgG responses (> _0.1 ISU) at 2 years of age in children with or without IgE sensitization at 2 years of age.
P values were calculated with x 2 or exact Fisher tests, when appropriate.
Significant differences are highlighted as follows: *P < .05,

The column on the right represents the exposure category (animal foods [red], vegetable foods [orange], inhaled [yellow], and others [grey]) to which the allergenic sources of individual molecules belong.
The marked boxes (#) refer to molecules used for analyses at the source level.

IgG to airborne sources at age 2 years with IgE to the same sources at age 7 years Overall, IgG responses at 2 years of age to the 91 molecules were only slightly more frequent among children with than in those without IgE sensitization at 7 years (40% vs 36%, P > .05).

IgG responses to 9 molecules only (Gal d 1, Pru p 1, Ara h 3, Act d 1, Act d 8, Der p 2, Art v 3, Can f 1, and Der p 1) were significantly more frequent among children with than those without IgE sensitization at 7 years of age (see the Results section, Fig E6 and Table
FIG 2. Prevalence and levels of IgG responses to allergenic sources in 148 children of the MAS cohort at 2 years of age by IgE sensitization at 2 years of age and main exposure route.

Circles show the prevalence (y-axis) and levels (diameter) of detectable IgG responses (> _0.1 ISU) to allergenic sources (see the Methods section for definition) at 2 years of age in children with (red) or without (blue) IgE sensitization at 2 years of age.
P values refer to comparisons of the prevalences and levels and were calculated with a x 2 and t test, respectively.
Statistically significant differences are highlighted as follows: *P < .05
for prevalence and 8P < .05
for level.
Dpt, D pteronyssinus.
FIG 3. Average prevalences and levels of IgG responses at 2 years of age to allergenic molecules by route of exposure in 123 nonsensitized and 25 IgE-sensitized 2-year-old children.
FIG E1.
Molecule selection at the source and category level.
FIG E2.
Prevalence of IgG 4 responses (cutoff, 0.1 ISU) to allergenic molecules at 2 years of age in 148 children of the MAS cohort.
FIG E3.
Relationship between IgG (y-axis) and IgG 4 (x-axis) levels to 91 allergenic molecules in a subset of 21 children of the MAS cohort.
Each serum has been tested against the 91 molecules in parallel for IgG and IgG 4 antibodies on the same day by the same operator.
Overall, 1911 comparisons have been performed.
and overcame 20% for 5 molecules only (Bos d 4, Bos d 5, Bos d 8, Gal d 2, and Der p 2; see Fig E2 in this article's Online Repository at www. jacionline.org).

In a subset analysis of 21 participants, IgG 4 levels were positive in only less than 5% of all tests performed and represented less than 3% of the IgG level in sera positive for both IgG and IgG 4 tested in the same laboratory session (Table II and see Fig E3 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.
org).
IgG 4 responses to most of the 38 molecules were more frequent or exclusively seen in participants with IgE sensitization (see Fig E4 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.
org).

Nevertheless, the propensity of IgE-sensitized children to produce a more frequent and stronger IgG response (Fig 1) persisted when the sera with IgG 4 responses to the examined molecule were excluded from the comparison (see Fig E5 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).
To test our working hypothesis, we analyzed the frequency and concentration of detectable IgG responses in IgE-sensitized and nonsensitized children at 2 years of age at the source level (Fig 2).

body.note: J ALLERGY CLIN IMMUNOL VOLUME 138, NUMBER 5

d The frequency and intensity of the IgG response induced by natural exposure to allergenic molecules is, at 2 years of age, highly dependent on the route of allergen exposure, being extremely frequent for animal food allergens, very frequent for vegetable food, and moderately frequent for airborne allergens.d These IgG responses are more frequent and stronger in children with current IgE sensitization.d The contribution of IgG 4 antibodies to this IgG response, which is induced by natural exposure, is marginal.
J ALLERGY CLIN IMMUNOL VOLUME 138, NUMBER 5 SCHWARZ ET AL 1433.e12

p.s: We thank Andreas Reich for management of the general MAS databank and Gabriele Schulz for management of the general MAS sera bank.
We thank Charles Clawson for English editing.
Furthermore, we thank all the families participating since 1990 in the German MAS birth cohort.
Among all collaborators, we thank especially M. G€ otz, P.
